I'm specifically asking about applying through job boards or through the "careers" portal on company websites in the US. I get a fair amount of interest from startups by posting here in the monthly "Who wants to be hired?" thread, but a month is a long time to wait when a job has become intolerable.

Any tips for beating ATS resume filters?

I skip and leave blank any section in a job application form that asks for information that's included in my resume like "work experience". Does skipping these invoke the ire of the ATS?

I also skip any demographic/disability/veteran status questions or choose "decline to answer". I assume there are serious legal strictures against taking those into consideration when evaluating a candidate.

How important is a cover letter? Is a two or three-sentence cover letter sufficient? necessary?

General online job hunting tips?
stories.title: Ask HN: Job Hunting – How to get your resume seen by a human?

stories.text:
It's 2022, torrent technology has been around for 15+ years.

So why is it still not trivial to host a file by torrent on a private network?

If I have a set of machines behind a firewall, it's a huge pain to setup a qbittorrent instance and configure clients to use it. Even once all that is setup, the retrieval process is nothing like "wget magnet://...".

To be clear, projects like aria2 (C++) and webtorrent (nodejs) do exist, but try to use them for anything production-ish grade or in an automated fashion and you'll find out they are slow to start the downloads and overall unreliable and flaky.

A true "wget" -style system for seeding and downloading from a private torrent swarm would be amazing for many use cases. I'm envisioning something like a program that monitors a folder and any file that ends up in the folder gets auto-seeded to a set of private clients.

What do you think?
stories.title: Ask HN: Why isn't it possible to easily host a file over torrent in 2022?
